06_01.question: Entities are a person, place, or thing.

06_02.question: Entities are further designed with attributes.

06_03.question: An entity is the basic building block for a data model.

06_04.question: Relationships are drawn with lines showing cardinality and plurality.
06_04.explanation: Relationships show cardinality and modality. Plurality is not a thing.

A.choice: Is a use-case diagram enhanced graphically to show data and process modeling

B.choice: Is a graphical display of the processes in a business system

C.choice: Is a high-level CASE diagram of data modeling used in business systems

D.choice: Is a picture that shows the information that is created, stored, and used by a business system

E.choice: Is an illustration of external data flows to and from a business systems

06_06.question: With an ERD, the diagrams are drawn in a sequential order – from top to bottom.
06_06.explanation: There's no order in an ERD.

06_07.question: On an ERD, data elements are described as singular (1:1); plurals (1:N); or didactic (M:N).
06_07.explanation: It's one-to-one (1:1), one-to-many (1:N), or many-to-many (M:N). "Singular", "Plurals", and "didatic" are made up.

06_08.question: Which would likely be an entity on a car insurance ERD?

06_09.question: In an entity called STUDENT, you might find attributes of Student-ID, Last-Name, First-Name and cell-phone.

06_10.question: Entity Relationship Diagrams show relationships between entities that are what?

E.choice: In line with the business rules and processing

06_11.question: An ERD is a picture that shows how data and information is processed and transformed by a business system.
06_11.explanation: ERD shows what data the system has, not how it's processed and transformed. That's more like a DFD.

06_12.question: Which would NOT likely be an attribute of an entity called "Student"?
06_12.explanation: A student is likely to have multiple classrooms, so there cannot be a single "Class room number" attribute.

06_13.question: A(n) _____ entity cannot exist without the presence of another entity or has an identifier that is based on another entity's attribute.

06_14.question: ERDs and DFDs are two techniques for process modeling.
06_14.explanation:
ERD = data modeling

DFD = process modeling

Not the same thing.

06_15.question: On an ERD, data elements are listed alphabetically with a cross listing to the processes that manipulate them.

06_16.question: On an ERD, processes are listed alphabetically with relationship connections drawn between processes.
06_16.explanation:
So many things wrong.
- ERDs do not have processes. That's for DFDs. 
- Neither ERDs nor DFDs are organized alphabetically.
- There are no such things as relationships between processes. There are relationships between entities, and data flows between processes.

06_17.question: On an ERD, data elements are listed together and place inside boxes called entities.

A.choice: When an entity comes from an external source (aka 'external entity')

B.choice: When there is only one entity for a data process model

C.choice: When an entity can exist without the help of another entity

D.choice: Where the entity identifier is also the primary key

E.choice: When a child requires attributes from the parent

06_19.question: A data model can do what?

A.choice: Illustrate return-on-investment, break-even point, and economic feasibility

B.choice: Be used as a logical data model in analysis and as a physical data model in design

C.choice: Only be used with JAD sessions

D.choice: Only be used in BPR situations

E.choice: Represent actions or processes that occur in the to-be system

06_20.question: Relationships are some type of information that is captured about entities.
06_20.explanation: Information captured about entities are *attributes*. Relationships are information about the system, particularly, about how entities are related to each other.

06_21.question: During the analysis phase logical data models are created.

06_22.question: Data modeling is an iterative process.
06_22.explanation: *"Work iteratively and constantly challenge the data model with business rules and exceptions to see whether the diagram is communicating the business system appropriately."* **(p. 189)**

06_23.question: With an ERD, special symbols are added to show high-level business rules.
06_23.explanation: There are symbols on relationship lines to indicate modality (whether the relationship is 1 to 1, 1 to many, or many to many). Modality shows business rules.

06_24.question: ERDs and DFDs are two techniques for data modeling.
06_24.explanation:
ERD = data modeling

DFD = process modeling

Not the same thing.

06_25.question: An illustration of the transformation of data into business value is an ERD.

06_26.question: In adding attributes to an ERD, which of the following might NOT be a good resource for attributes?

D.choice: Through interviews (what users need for reports and processing)

06_26.explanation: The system proposal is the final deliverable of the Analysis phase, after you've done the ERD. You cannot use the system proposal to create ERDs, because it doesn't exist yet.

06_27.question: Anthony is working on the cardinality of doctors and patients in a large urban hospital. With the large number of doctors with varying specialties and patients that may have more than one aliment, he thinks the relationship might be noted as what?

06_28.question: On an ERD, data elements are grouped in a hierarchical structure that is uniquely identified by number.
06_28.explanation: There is no hierachical structure in an ERD, and entities are referred to by names (e.g. the Car entity), not ID number.

06_29.question: In creating ERD's, which would most likely NOT be a source for entities?

06_30.question: The three steps in creating an ERD are: (1) identify the entities; (2) identify the attributes; (3) identify the relationships

06_31.question: The first step to building an Entity Relationship Diagram is to do what?

A.choice: Identify data flows from the level 0 DFD diagram

B.choice: identify the attributes for each entity

D.choice: identify the processes, data flows and data stores

E.choice: draw the relationships between the entities

06_32.question: Data models can be either logical or physical.

06_33.question: The last step in creating basic ERD's is to:

06_34.question: An entity is which of the following?

B.choice: Is a person, place or thing

C.choice: Is described with a verb phrase

D.choice: Shows if it can be null or no null

E.choice: Is the association between two related processes

06_35.question: A data model is a what?

A.choice: The abstract creating of an ideal system transformation

B.choice: A formal way of representing the data that are used and created by a business system

C.choice: The expanded, thoroughly balanced and normalized use case for a system

D.choice: The mathematical model of formulas and logic used in a system

E.choice: The model that is produced by extreme programming

06_36.question: In an entity called STUDENT, you might find attributes of PROFESSOR-ID, Last-Name, First-Name and CLASSROOM.
06_36.explanation: A student is likely to have multiple professors and classrooms, so there cannot be a single "Professsor-ID" or "Classroom" attribute.

06_38.question: What type of process is creating an ERD?

06_39.question: The three major parts of an ERD diagram are what?
06_39.explanation:
ERDs do not have process, data flow, data store; those are in DFDs.

"Modularity" is not a thing. 

ERDs also have modality and cardinality, but these are properties of relationships, so they are not considered "major".

06_40.question: A data model is a formal way of representing the data that are used and created by a business system.

06_41.question: One of the most commonly used techniques for data modeling is ERDs.

06_42.question: One of the first places to start developing Entity Relationship Diagrams is by looking at the level 0 process models (DFD) and the use cases for data flows and data stores.

06_43.question: With an ERD, lines are drawn to show relationships among the data.

06_44.question: Lines on an ERD diagram indicate what?

06_45.question: A graphical illustration that shows the information that is created, stored, and used by a business system would be an ERD.

06_46.question: The three steps in creating an ERD are: (1) identify the entities; (2) identify the processes; (3) identify the relationships
06_46.explanation: There are no processes in an ERD. ERDs have entities, *attributes*, and relationships. Only DFDs have processes.

06_47.question: Jack is developing an ERD for a small dental practice office patient record system. The dental practice has three dentists, six hygienists, and many patients. A patient is always assigned to the same dentist for all appointments. In particular, he is working on the relationship between dentists and patients. Should it be which of the following?

A.choice: 1 to 1, with a modality of null

B.choice: 1 to many with a modality of null

C.choice: Many to many with a modality of null

D.choice: Many to many with a modality of not null

E.choice: 1 to many with a modality of not null

06_48.question: The lines that connect the entities are referred to as

06_49.question: With an ERD, similar kinds of information are listed together in entities.

06_51.question: An analyst can read an ERD to discover the individual pieces of information in a system and how they are organized and related to each other.

06_52.question: ERDs are drawn in several levels: Context ERD diagrams; Level 0 ERD diagrams; Level 1 ERD diagrams.
06_52.explanation: Trick question. There are context DFD, level 1 DFD, and level 2 DFD. There are no such things for ERD.

06_53.question: An entity is described by an action verb.
06_53.explanation: Entity is described by a noun. Described by an action verb is a process.

06_54.question: You have entities of ITEM, SOLD-ITEM, SALE and PAYMENT. Which most likely is NOT a relationship?
06_54.explanation: The correct relationships are "PAYMENT pays for SOLD-ITEM includes ITEM"

06_55.question: Modality refers to which of the following?

A.choice: Relationships of one-to-one; one-to-many; or many-to-many

B.choice: The number of attributes generated by an entity

C.choice: Whether the entity has a unique identifier (aka 'primary key') or a concatenated identifier (aka 'composite key')

D.choice: The hierarchical structure that was developed in process models applied to data models

E.choice: Whether and entity can exist with or without a related instance in the related entity

06_56.question: During the analysis phase, analysts create programming models to represent how the business system will operate.

06_57.question: Which would NOT likely be an entity on a car insurance ERD?
06_57.explanation: Zip code would more likely be an attribute. An entity should be a person, a place, or a thing.

06_58.question: A(n) _____ entity is an entity with an identifier that describes only the entity.

06_59.question: ERDs can be quite complex and might have hundreds or thousands of entities.

06_60.question: Information in the data dictionary is called what?

06_61.question: An ERD is a picture which shows the information that is ________ by a business system.

06_63.question: On an ERD, similar kinds of information are listed together and placed inside boxes called data containers.

06_64.question: In defining the data characteristics of Universal Product Codes, we might describe them as twelve characters made up of digits – numeric only.

06_65.question: Andrew, an analyst for PaxMedia Inc., has just learned that the business rules for a system he has been working on have changed. This means what?

A.choice: Andrew will be reassigned to a different project that is in its beginning stages

B.choice: The project will have to be scrapped and restarted

C.choice: The ERD data model will have to be put on hold while new DFD diagrams are created

D.choice: The ERD components will have to be changed

E.choice: Nothing – once the ERD data models have been drawn, they are 'frozen' for the system

06_65.explanation: *"When business rules change, the relationships or other data model components will have to be altered."* **(p. 189)**

06_66.question: In the analysis phase of the SDLC, our data models should include all the technical details necessary to ensure the efficiency of data storage and retrieval.

06_67.question: ERD is the only way to model data requirements for the system.

06_68.question:
TopText Publishing is a textbook publishing company with a headquarter location, a warehouse, and three sales offices. Each of the sale offices has a sales manager and one or more sales reps. TopText sells to schools, colleges, and individual customers. TopText maintains an active list of more than 100 books they have published so far, each identified by a universal code called an ISBN. Authors may write more than one book for TopText, and some books have multiple authors.

Based on the data requirements, which of the following should be entities in the ERD?

06_69.question: An intersection entity often has two identifiers.

06_70.question:
"A pilot cannot be on duty for more than 10 hours during a 24-hour period."

If the following ERD models the business rule above, what are the required attributes for the entity DUTY so that we can guarantee the constraint on the hours of flights for pilots?

06_71.question:
What is the type of relationship between PROFESSOR and CLASS as described in the business rule:

"A professor may teach up to four classes during a semester."

06_72.question: A relationship is always between two different entities.

06_73.question: Select all business rules that are consistent with the following data model.

A.choice: Each EMPLOYEE must have at least one PERFORMANCE_REVIEW.

B.choice: Every JOB_SKILL is associated with at least one EMPLOYEE.

06_74.question:
A company is designing a new customer support ticketing system. They want to map out how customer issues move through the system from submission to resolution.

Which modeling approach should they use?

06_75.question:
A systems analyst is designing a ride-sharing app and wants to model:
  • User requests a ride.
  • Driver accepts the request.
  • Ride is completed, and payment is processed.
Which representation is most effective for modeling these interactions?

06_76.question:
A company tracks employees and projects. Each employee can be assigned to multiple projects, and each project can have multiple employees working on it. In addition each project is assigned to only one employee who manages it.

Which of the following ERDs best represents these business rules?

B.choice: EMPLOYEE → is assigned to → PROJECT → manages → MANAGER

D.choice: EMPLOYEE → is assigned to & manages → PROJECT

06_77.question:
A hospital system tracks patients and doctors. A patient must have a doctor assigned, but doctors may have zero or more patients assigned.

Which of the following correctly represents this relationship?

06_78.question:
A company tracks employee salaries. Managers need to view past salary changes to understand how compensation has evolved.

Which is the best approach for modeling this?

A.choice: Only store the current salary of each employee.

B.choice: Overwrite the salary data each time an employee gets a raise.

C.choice: Maintain a separate salary history, tracking all salary changes over time.

D.choice: Store salary information in the employee entity, along with previous salaries in separate columns.

06_79.question: An Entity Relationship model may be implemented as a non-relational database.

06_80.question:
A library system allows members to check out books. Each member can borrow up to 5 books at a time.

Which of the following ERDs best guarantee the borrowing limit of 5 books at a time for a member of the library?

A.choice: MEMBER with NUM_BORROWED attribute connected to BORROWING intersection entity

B.choice: Simple many-to-many relationship between MEMBER and BOOK
